bestBHT.bht: The Lamb, in the midst of the throne, acts as a shepherd, guiding the redeemed towards the fountains of life-giving waters. As God wipes away every tear, the image of living fountains of water symbolizes the everlasting happiness of heaven. In this realm, pain, disappointment, and loss will be no more. With the Lamb as their provider, the redeemed will never hunger or thirst again. Christ, the King of saints, will reign magnificently, and the grace and love of God will abundantly flow like a river of life.

Henry Alford: The Lamb which is in the midst of the throne shall tend them (as a shepherd his flock), and shall guide them to the fountains of the waters of life."
God shall wipe away every tear out of their eyes."
THE LAST SEAL IS NOW OPENED, which lets loose the roll.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: in the midst of the throne—that is, in the middle point in front of the throne
living fountains of water—A, B, Vulgate, and CYPRIAN read, (eternal) 'life's fountains of waters.'
Albert Barnes: For the Lamb, which is in the midst of the throne - notes on Revelation 5:6. He is still the great agent in promoting the happiness of the redeemed in heaven.

And shall lead them unto living fountains of waters - Living fountains refer to running streams, as contrasted with standing water and stagnant pools. The allusion is undoubtedly to the happiness of heaven, represented as fresh and everflowing, like streams in the desert. No image of happiness, perhaps, is more vivid, or would be more striking to an Oriental, than that of such fountains flowing in sandy and burning wastes.

And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes - This is a new image of happiness taken from another place in Isaiah Isaiah 25:8, 'The Lord God will wipe away tears from off all faces.' The expression is one of exquisite tenderness and beauty... Yet this is to be the condition of heaven. In that world there is to be no pain, no disappointment, no bereavement.
Marvin Vincent: Shall feed [ποιμανει] . See on shall be shepherd of, Matthew 2:6; Acts 20:28; 1 Peter 5:2. Compare Psalms 23:1.
Living fountains of waters [ζωσας πηγας υδατων] . For the participle living, read zwhv of life, and render as Rev., fountains of waters of life. Compare Psalms 23:2.
Archibald T. Robertson: Shall shepherd them," future active of ποιμαινω (from ποιμην, shepherd), in John 21:16; Acts 20:28; 1 Peter 5:2; Revelation 2:27; Revelation 7:17; Revelation 12:5; Revelation 19:15. Jesus is still the Good Shepherd of his sheep (John 10:11; John 10:14). Cf. Psalms 23:1.

Shall guide them" (οδη γησε αυτους). Future active of οδηγεω, old word (from οδηγος, guide, Matthew 15:14), used of God's guidance of Israel (Exodus 15:13), of God's guidance of individual lives (Psalms 5:9), of the guidance of the Holy Spirit (John 16:13), of Christ's own guidance here (cf. John 14:4; Revelation 14:4).
Words like these of vv. Revelation 7:15-17 must sound as a divine music in the ears of the persecuted. God will comfort as a mother comforts" (Baljon).
John Gill: Christ will now be visibly King of saints, and King over all the earth, and will reign before his ancients gloriously.
By 'water' is meant the grace, love, and free favour of God in Christ, that pure river of water of life, which proceeds from the throne of God, and of the Lamb, from divine sovereignty.
That which is now the occasion of tears will cease...and in the room of them full and everlasting joy will take place.
John Wesley: For the Lamb will feed them... so that they shall hunger no more.
And will lead them to living fountains of water... so that they shall thirst no more.
Neither shall they suffer or grieve any more; for God 'will wipe away all tears from their eyes.'

bhtAttempts.bht: In the midst of the throne, the Lamb, who tends to them like a shepherd, will lead the redeemed to the fountains of life-giving waters. As God wipes away every tear from their eyes in this moment when the last seal is opened, the image of the Lamb as the shepherd and guide brings comfort to the persecuted. The living fountains of water represent the fresh and everflowing happiness of heaven, contrasting with the arid deserts. In this realm, there will be no pain, disappointment, or loss. Christ, the King of saints, will reign gloriously, and the grace and love of God will flow abundantly like a river of life. Hunger and thirst will be no more as the Lamb provides and leads the redeemed to eternal satisfaction.

In the midst of the throne, the Lamb, as a shepherd, will guide the redeemed to the fountains of life-giving waters. God wiping away every tear signifies the comfort offered to the persecuted. The image of living fountains of water represents the everflowing happiness of heaven. In this realm, there will be no pain. Christ, as the King of saints, will reign gloriously, and the grace and love of God will flow abundantly. The Lamb will provide nourishment and lead the redeemed to eternal satisfaction, where hunger and thirst will be no more.

Christ, as the King of saints, will reign gloriously, and the grace and love of God will flow abundantly. As God wipes away every tear, the image of living fountains of water represents the everlasting happiness of heaven. There, pain, disappointment, and loss will cease to exist. With the Lamb as their provider, the redeemed will no longer hunger or thirst. Christ, the King of saints, will reign gloriously and the grace and love of God will flow abundantly like a river of life.
